div.p:
I have had your letter for several days and only an=
swer answer just now not you may believe from what of interest in
the contents but from the odd circumstance of being so much
aflicted afflicted with chill blains in the fingers that my pen
scrambles every way but the right one: Assuredly I should secure
the character of a most crabbed fellow from these modern
sages who judge of a man from his hand writing handwriting . But as
an old man becomes twice a child I must expect I suppose
measles & small pox smallpox I only wish I could get a first set
of teeth. To tell you the truth I feel the advance of age more
than I like though my general health is excellent but
I am not able to walk as I did and I fear I could not now
visit Saint Kevans Kevin's bed This is a great affliction to one
who has been so active as I have been in spite of all disad=
vantages disadvantages I must now have a friendly arm instead of
relying on my own exertions and it is sad to think I
shall be worse before I am better. However the mild
weather may help me in some degree & the worst is
a quiet perry (I use to detest a quiet perry) as perhaps
a garden chair

All this does not prevent my sincere sympathy in
the increase of your family happiness which I hope Miss Fannys
marriage will afford to herself to you and all who love her
I have not had the same opportunity to know her merits

those of my friends Mrs Butler and
Mrs. Fox Lane But I saw
enough of her (being your sister) when at Dublin to feel most
sincerely interested in a young person whose exterior is so amiable
and I am sure she must partake of the talents and good
feelings of her sisters to deserve the kindest and best wishes
of a friend of your family on the present interesting occasion
In Mr Wilson you describe the national character John Bull
who is not the worst of three natures though he has not the greater
feeling and rich humour humor of your countrymen nor the shrewd sagacity
of
or the romantic spirit of thinking and adventuring
which
the Scotch often conceal under their apparent coldness and which you
have so well painted in that of McLeod in ennui Depend and
I will find Russell Square when I go to London were I be here a vessel
of discovery to make it out and it will be Mr Wilsons fault if we do
not make an internal-acquaintance.

I had the pleasure of receiving your American friend Miss Douglas
who seems a most ingenuous person She is sad want however of
some one to teach her some points of tact in society which are
necessary to regulate the best feelings and to correct the enthusiasm
of
Columbian Colombian
independence. But I was as kind and civil
to her as her time and my own permitted me to be and I hope
I was successful in making her happy during her short visit
at abbotsford for I was compelld compelled to leave her to pay suit & service
at the circuit

The mention of the Circuit brings me to the horrors which you
have so well described and which resemble nothing so much
as a wild dream. Certainly I thought like you that the publick public
alarm was but an exaggeration of vulgar rumour rumor but the tragedy
is too true & I look in vain for a remedy of the evils though it
easy to see them in which this black & unnatural business
has found its accursed origin
The principal source certainly originates in the feelings

of attachment which the Scotch have for their deceased friends & they are curious
in the choice of their place of
sepuhlre sepulchre
and a common shepherd is often at Whateve
ruinous expence expense to his family transported many miles to some favoured favored place
of
sepuhlre sepulchre
which has been occupied by his fathers It follows of course
that any interference with their remains are is considered th with most
utter horror & indignation To each of their superriors as they live from clan
ship or habits of dependence, they attach the same feeling of attachment
I experienced it when I had a great domestic loss for I learned after
ward afterward that the cemetery was guarded, out of good will by the
servants and dependants dependents who had been attached to her during life and
were I to be laid beside my lost companion just now I have no doubt it would
be long before my humble friends would discontinue the same watch over my
remains and that it would incur mortal
risque risk
to approach them with
the purpose of violation. This is on a kind and virtuous principle which
every one so far partakes that although an unprejudiced person would
have no
objections to the idea of his own remains undergoing dissection
if their being exposed to scientific research could be of the least service to
humanity yet we all shudder at the exposure of any who had
been dear to us especially a wife or sister being subjected to a scalpel
among a gazing and unfeeling crowd of students - One would
fight and die to prevent it - This current of feeling is encouraged by the
law which as distinguishing murderers and other atrocious criminals orders
that their bodies should be given for publick public dissection. This makes it al=
most almost impossible to assign publickly publicly the bodies of those who die in
the publick public hospitals to the same fate for it would bring inflicting
on poverty the penalty which wisely or unwisely the same law of the
court country has denounced against guilt of the highest degree & it
would assuredly deprive all who have a remaining spark of feeling or
shame, of the benefit of those consolations of charity of which they
are the best objects. This natural prejudice deeply seated
to be eradicated. If not very liberal, it is surely natural of the
best feelings must be destroyed ere it can be eradicated What then
remains - The only idea I see is to permit importatation from other coun
triescountries

countries If a subject can be hard in Paris for 10 or 20 franks it will surely
pay the importer who brings it to Scotland & if the medicalmen find
it convenient to use more economy they will teach anatomy g in all
surgical purposes equally will though they may not make such advances
in physiology. Something must be done for there is an end of the Cantabit
vacuus the last prerogative of beggary which entitled him to laugh at the
risquerisk
of robbery. the veriest wretch in the highway may be better booty than
a person of consideration since the last has may have but a few shillings
in his pocket and the beggar being once dead is worth ten pounds to his
murderer

The great number of the lower Irish which have come over here since
the peace is like all important occurrences attended with its own share
of good and evil. It must relieve Ireland in part of the excess of population
which is one of its greatest evils and it accommodates Scotland into with
a race of hardy and indefatigable labourers laborers without which it would
impossible to carry on the very expensive improvements which have been
executed Our canals our railrods and our various public works are all
wrought by Irish I have often employed them myself at burning clay
and similar operations - I have found these labourers laborers quiet and
tractable light-spirited too, and happy to a degree beyond be
-lief belief and in no degree quarrelsome Keep whisky from them and them from
whisky - But most unhappily for all parties they work at far too
low a rate, at a rate in short, which can but just procure salt and po-
tatoes potatoes They become reckless of course of all the comforts and decencies
of life which they have no means of procuring Extreme poverty brings
ignorance and vice and these are the mothers of crime If Ireland
were to submit to some kind of poor rate (I do not mean that of
England) but something that should secure to the indigent their
natural share of the fruits of the earth and might enable them
at least to feed while others are feasting it would apparently raise
the character of the lower-orders, and deprive them of that reckless
ness recklessness of futurity which leads them to think only of the present. Indeed
where intoxication of the lower ranks is mentioned as a vice we
must

temptation is well nigh inevitable Meat clothes, fire all that men
can and do want are supplied by a drop of whisky, and no one
should be surprised that the relief (too often the only one within
the wretches power) is eagerly grasped at. We pay back I suspect
the inconveniences we receive from the character of our Irish impor
tation importation by sending you a set of half educated half-educated , cold hearted cold-hearted
Scotchmen to be agents and middlemen Among them too, there are
good and excellent characters yet I can conceive they often mis
lead mislead their English employers.

I am no great believer in the extreme degree of inform improvement
to be derived from the advancement of science for every pursuit of that
nature tends when pushed to a certain extent to harden the heart &
render the philosopher reckless of every thing save the objects of his
own pursuit; all equilibrium in the character is destroyed and
the visual nerve of the understanding is perverted by being fixed
on one object exclusively. Thus we see theological sects (although
inculcating the moral doctrines) are eternally placing man’s zeal
in opposition to them & even in the calling it is astonishing how
we become callous to right and wrong when the question is to gain
or lose a cause & I have myself often wondered how I became so
indifferent to the horrors of a criminal trial In if it involved a
point of law In like manner the pursuit of physical studies in
flicts inflicts tortures on the lower animals of creation and at length
comes to rub shoulders against the West Port. The state of high
civilisation civilization to which we have arrived, is perhaps scarcely a
national blessing since while the few are improved to the highest
point the many are in proportion tantalized and degraded &
the same nation displays at the same time the very highest and the
very lowest state in which the human race can exist in point of
intellect. Here is a Dr who is able to take down the whole clock work
of the human frame & may in time find some way of repairing
and putting it together again and there is Burke with the body
Here, Scott is referring to the Burke and Hare murders. These murders were a string of sixteen killings where Burke and Hare killed and sold corpses to Dr. Knox for medical dissection.

murdered countrywoman on his back & her blood on his hands
asking his price for the body from the learned carcass
butcher. After all the Golden Age was the period for general hap
piness when the Earth gave its stores Without labour labor and the
people wereexisted only in the numbers which it could easily
subsist but this was too good to last As our numbers increased our
wants multiplied and here we are contending with increasing
difficulties by the force of repeated inventions. Whether we shall
at last eat each other as of yore, or whether the earth will get a
flap with a comets tail first who but the reverend Mr
Irving will venture to pronounce.
Now here is a fearful long letter and the next thing
is to send under Lord Levesen Gowers omnipotent frank.
Anne sends best compliments she says she had the honour to
despatch her congratulations to you already. Walter and his
little wife are at Nice He is now Major of his Regiment, which
is rapid advancement & so has gone abroad to see the world.
Lockhart has been here for a week but is now gone for England I
suspect he is at this moment stopped by the snow storm and so
=lacing solacing himself with a cigar somewhere in
North
humberland Northumberland
. That is all the news that can interest you
Dr and Mrs Brewster are rather getting over their heavy loss
but it is still too visible on their brows and that broad river lying
daily before them is a cruel remembrancer I saw a brother of
yours on a visit there, he dined with us one day and promised to
come and see us which I hope he will make good My pen has
been declaring itself independent this half hour which is the
more unnatural as it is engaged in writing to its former
mistress
